questions.text: The nerve of the second branchial arch is _________________
questions.solution:
The facial nerve is the nerve of the 2nd pharyngeal arch. 

 

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Branchial Apparatus

Arch Nerve Skeletal derivatives Pouch Derivatives Muscle Derivatives Artery 

1st (mandibular arch)

 Trigeminal (V) - Maxillary and mandibular divisions
  • Incus
  • Malleus
  • Anterior ligament of malleus
  • Spine of sphenoid
  • Sphenomandibular ligament
  • Auditory tube
  • Middle ear cavity 
  • Tensor tympani
  • Muscles of mastication 
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor veli palatini
  • Maxillary artery

2nd (hyoid arch)

 Facial (VII)
  • Stapes
  • Styloid process (temporal)
  • Lesser cornu and upper hyoid
  • Stylohyoid ligament
  • Palatine tonsil
  • Tonsillar fossa 
  • Stapedius
  • Stylohyoid 
  • Facial Muscles (Buccinator, Platysma, Posterior belly of digastric)
  • Stapedial artery
  • Hyoid artery
3rd Glossopharyngeal (IX)
  • Greater cornu of hyoid
  • Lower part of hyoid body
  • Inferior parathyroids
  • Thymus 
  • Stylopharyngeus
  • Common carotid
  • Proximal internal carotid arteries

  • Parafollicular C cells of Thyroid (from ultimobranchial body)
 
  • Pharyngeal muscles
  • Larynx -Cricothyroid
  • Levator veli palatini

  • Left side: Arch of the aorta from the left common carotid to the left subclavian arteries
6th Recurrent laryngeal of Vagus (X)
  • Arytenoid cartilages
 		  
  • All intrinsic muscles of the larynx (except the cricothyroid muscle)
  • Right side: right pulmonary artery 
  • Left side: left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus

questions.text: Conscious proprioception is carried by_____.
questions.solution:
Conscious proprioception is carried by dorsal column. Unconscious proprioception is carried by spinocerebellar tract.

Option B and C: Anterolateral system carries pain, temperature, crude touch.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin is the most potent and naturally occurring antioxidant?
questions.solution:
Vitamin E is the most potent and naturally occurring antioxidant.

Protective antioxidant nutrients:

  • Selenium
  • Vitamin C
  • Vitamin E
  • β-carotene (vitamin A)and other carotenoids
  • Polyphenolic compounds derived from plant foods

Therapeutic uses of high dose of Vitamin E:

1)Retrolental fibroplasia

2)Bronchopulmonary dysplasia

3)Intraventricular hemorrhage

4)Used for treatment of intermittent claudication.

questions.text: All are true about Hashimoto’s thyroiditis except______.
questions.solution:
All the above features are seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis except orphan annie eye nuclei. Orphan Annie eye nuclei are seen in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Hashimoto thyroiditis

  • An autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual and progressive thyroid failure.
  • Presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase
  • Most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas of the world where iodine levels are sufficient
  • Female predominance
  • Thyroid often diffusely enlarged, painless, with some degree of hypothyroidism
  • May be preceded by transient thyrotoxicosis (“hashitoxicosis”).
  • Extensive infiltration of the parenchyma by small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centers
  • The thyroid follicles are atrophic and are lined in many areas by Hürthle cells.
  • Increased risk of developing other autoimmune diseases.
  • Increased risk for the development of extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphomas and papillary carcinoma within the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A 2 year old child is brought to the OPD with oral and perioral lesions as seen in the image below. Similar lesions were also found on his palms and soles. What is the probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease that is caused by coxsackie A virus.

Hand, foot, and mouth disease initially begins with fever and sore throat following which blisters develop over the oral cavity, hands and feet.

It usually occurs in children but may also occur in adults. It is a self limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks.

The following images show lesions affecting hands and feet:

Other options:

Option B: Molluscum contagiosum presents as umbilicated nodules and not vesicles.

Option C: Parvovirus B19 infection occurs usually in children 5–10 years causing erythema infectiosum. It is also known as fifth disease. It begins as a prominent erythema of the cheeks- slapped cheek disease, spreading to the trunk and limbs, followed by lymphadenopathy and arthralgia

Option D: Streptococcus causes red sores around the mouth and the nose in impetigo. It forms a characteristic honey-coloured scab and is not associated with lesions on palms and soles. The given image shows impetigo.

questions.text: Hemorrhagic cystitis is a characteristic side effect of _______.
questions.solution: Hemorrhagic cystitis is a characteristic side effect of cyclophosphamide. The metabolite responsible for hemorrhagic cystitis is acrolein. This can be decreased by vigorous hydration and by the use of mercapto ethane sulfonic acid (mesna).

questions.text: McNaughten's rule falls under which Section?
questions.solution:
McNaughten's rule falls under section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). Mc Naughten's rule (The right or wrong test / The legal test) states that "A person of unsound mind is not liable for an act."

Defect : In Mc Naughthen’s rule , only intellectual factors are considered but emotions, delusion and control of impulses are ignored.

Related Pearl: IPC Sec 84, McNaughten's rule

McNaughten's rule, Section 84 IPC:  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

It states that an accused is not criminally responsible if he was suffering from:

  • Defect of reason and unsoundness of mind: the law recognizes only those diseases which impair the thinking abilities of the mind. So, not all medically insane people are legally insane, as emotional disturbances that affect the mind are not considered if they do not directly affect cognition.
  • That he did not know the nature and the quality of the act he is doing:  the law needs the unsoundness of mind to exist at the time of the act to such a degree that the person is not aware of what he is doing and whether it is right or wrong to do. Absence of a motive or forethought is also considered as a criteria for determining unsoundness of mind.

McNaughten’s rule now comes under Section 22 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023.

questions.text: Ohngren’s classification is related to:
questions.solution:
Ohngren’s classification is used for maxillary carcinoma.

An imaginary plane is drawn, extending between medial canthus of eye and the angle of mandible.

Ohngren's line(below image):

Growths situated above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it (infrastructural).

questions.text: The given sago-grain appearance of conjunctiva is seen in ________
questions.solution:
The given sago-grain appearance of conjunctiva is seen in trachoma.

Conjunctival appearance:

1. In trachoma

  • Sago-grain appearance
  • A follicular reaction

2. In vernal keratoconjunctivitis

  • Cobblestone appearance
  • A papillary reaction
  • Seen in palpebral conjunctiva

3. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis

  • White-pinkish nodule in bulbar conjunctiva

4. Xerophthalmia

  • Epithelial xerosis
  • Bitots spot in bulbar conjunctiva

questions.text: Which of the following diseases are included in the scheme ,which has the logo as given below?
questions.solution:
The logo shows the NPCDCS scheme that has separate components for cancer and other non-communicable diseases like diabetes, cardiovascular disease and stroke.

The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS) has specialized facilities in district hospitals.

It has been implemented in over 100 districts in 21 states.

At the subcentre level under NPCDCS, screening and referral is done.

NOTE: Non-alcoholic fattly liver disease (NAFLD) has been integrated with NPCDCS in 2021.

questions.text: When information related to health is used to spread a particular systemized doctrine or a political viewpoint to instill it in the minds of the people, what is it called?
questions.solution:
When information is used to spread a particular systemized doctrine it is called Health propaganda.

The difference between health education and health propaganda is given below:

  Health education  Health propaganda
Knowledge Actively acquired Instilled in the mind
Skills Actively acquired Instilled
Primitive desires Disciplined Aroused
Action Reflective behaviour; trained to use judgement before acting Reflexive behaviour; Aims at impulsive action 
Emotion  Does not appeal to emotion but appeals to reason Appeals to emotion
Behaviour The process is behaviour centred  The process is information centred

 

Four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach: Governmental intervention, direct or indirect, designed to alter human behaviour. It may range from prohibition to imprisonment.
  • Service approach: Providing all health services needed by people at their doorstep on the assumption that people would use them to improve their own health.
  • Health education approach: People must be educated through planned learning experiences on what to do, and be informed, educated and encouraged to make their own choice for a healthy life.
  • Primary health care approach: Full participation and active involvement in planning and delivery of health services based on principles of primary health care viz community involvement and intersectoral coordination.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best study design to prove causation?
questions.solution:
Randomized controlled trial (RCT) is the strongest and best study design to prove causation.

Case–control and cohort studies have moderate ability to provide evidence for causality.

Ecological studies or correlational studies are considered as the weakest study design in this aspect.

questions.text: What is not a feature of Myasthenia Gravis among the following?
questions.solution:
Absent deep tendon reflex is not a feature of myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. Reflexes are normal in Myasthenia gravis.
The underlying defect is a decrease in the number of available acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at neuromuscular junction due to an antibody-mediated autoimmune attack.

questions.text: Identify the tachycardia depicted in the given ECG.
questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of atrial flutter.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes, hence it is supraventricular tachycardia. The RR intervals are regular and the normal P waves are replaced by sawtooth-shaped waves (red arrows), known as flutter waves. Hence, it is most likely to be atrial flutter.

In atrial flutter, the ventricular rate is determined by the AV conduction ratio. The commonest AV ratio is 2:1. As the atrial rate is around 300 bpm, AV conduction ratio of 2:1 results in a ventricular rate of ~150 bpm.

questions.text: An HIV-positive individual presents with the following. What is the diagnosis &  WHO clinical stage of HIV?
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis (Thrush) is characterized in WHO Clinical Stage 3.

Oral Candidiasis (Thrush), and oral hairy leukoplakia, are oral lesions characterized in WHO clinical Stage 3. They generally occur in patients with CD4+ T cell counts of <300/μL.

Differentiating oral candidiasis and oral hairy leukoplakia:

  • Oral Candidiasis (Thrush) appears as a white, cheesy exudate, on an erythematous mucosa in the posterior oropharynx. The diagnosis is made by direct examination of pseudohyphal elements.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia presents as white, frondlike lesions, generally along the lateral borders of the tongue and sometimes on the adjacent buccal mucosa(image below). Despite its name, oral hairy leukoplakia is not considered premalignant. Lesions are associated with Ebstein barr virus (EBV).

questions.text: A diagnosis of gouty arthritis is made after aspiration of the synovial fluid and polarised light microscopy shows negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals.  These crystals are
questions.solution:
Negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals seen on polarised light microscopy in gouty arthritis is due to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals.

Other options:

Option A- Calcium apatite crystals can accumulate in areas of tissue damage, hypercalcemic, or hyperparathyroid states.

Option C- Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are rhomboid-shaped and are seen in pseudogout.

Option D- Calcium Oxalate crystals are seen in chronic renal failure.

Monosodium urate crystals in gout-

Calcium pyrophosphate crystals seen in pseudogout-

questions.text: Parathyroid gland post surgery  is commonly transferred to:
questions.solution:
Parathyroid is commonly transferred to brachioradialis muscle post surgery.

When multiple parathyroids are resected, parathyroid tissue is transplanted to the non-dominant forearm. Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of swelling in the right groin for the past 6 months. On examination, an irreducible hernia is present in the right groin. Which of the following structures would be helpful in identifying if the hernia is inguinal or femoral in origin?
questions.solution:
Pubic tubercle is used to differentiate between inguinal and femoral hernias.

Inguinal hernia is above and medial to the pubic tubercle.

Femoral hernia is below and lateral to the pubic tubercle.

Another structure that is useful in differentiating between inguinal and femoral hernia is inguinal ligament. An inguinal hernia leaves the abdominal cavity just above the inguinal ligament and a femoral hernia leaves just below the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: A 3-year-old is brought with superficial and deep second degree burns on his chest. What is the most accurate method to assess the total body surface area involved ?

choices.text: Using the child's  palm as reference

questions.solution:
Lund and Browder chart gives a more accurate accounting of the true burn size in children.

Unlike the Wallace rule of nines, the Lund and Browder chart takes into consideration the age of the person, by decreasing percentage BSA (Body Surface Area) for the head and increasing percentage BSA for the legs as the child ages, making it more useful in pediatric burns.

questions.text: Which is the most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis?
questions.solution:
The most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis is Escherichia coli.

Acute bacterial prostatitis

  • Acute inflammation of the prostate associated with urinary tract infection (UTI).
  • Other than E. coli, Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus albus, Streptococcus faecalis, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, or Chlamydia species may also be responsible.
  • Caused by ascending urethral infection or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts.
  • Treatment: Trimethoprim-sulphamethoxazole and ciprofloxacin for 4–6 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to OCP use?
questions.solution:
Thromboembolism is an absolute contraindication to OCP use.

Contraindications of OCPs:

  • Absolute contraindications -
    • Breast and genital cancers
    • Liver disease
    • History of thromboembolism- DVT, stroke
    • Congenital hyperlipidemia
    • Undiagnosed AUB.
  • Relative contraindications - 
     
    • Pregnancy
    • Uncontrolled hypertension
    • Chronic renal disease
    • If she is a smoker aged >35 years
    • Migraine with aura
    • First 6 months of nursing
    • Diabetes with vascular involvement
    • Gallbladder disease
    • History of infrequent bleeding or amenorrhea

questions.text: A multigravida woman at 33 weeks of gestation presents with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, blood pressure 170/100mm Hg, and proteinuria - 3+. She was given a loading dose of 14g MgSO4, followed by 5g intramuscularly every 4 hours in the alternate buttocks. Which regimen is being followed here?
questions.solution:
A 33 Weeks multigravida woman presents with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, blood pressure of 170/100mm Hg, and proteinuria -3+ which indicates severe preeclampsia. The administration of MgSO4 is being given here is by the Pritchard regimen.

MgSO4 regimens for management of eclampsia and severe preeclampsia:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2g/h IV infusion

Repeat injections of MgSO4 are given only if:

  • Knee jerks are present
  • Urine output > 30 mL/h
  • Respiratory rate > 12/minute

It is continued for 24 hours after the last seizure or delivery whichever is later.

questions.text: Which of the following is a part of AMTSL?
questions.solution:
Controlled cord traction during placental delivery is a component of AMTSL (Active management of third stage of labour).

AMTSL recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate (within 1 minute) administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV. Generally, it should be given after delivery of the fetus and before the delivery of the placenta. 
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women(done every 15 minutes for 2 hours)

Uterine massage is not a part of AMTSL. During the uterine tone assessment to ensure a contracted uterus, if there is uterine atony, a fundal massage is performed. 

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum haemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor to decrease PPH.

questions.text: The most common anomaly in a child presenting with recurrent urinary tract infections is _______.
questions.solution:
The most common cause of recurrent urinary tract infection in children is vesicoureteric reflux.

VUR occurs when the submucosal tunnel between the mucosa and detrusor muscle is short or absent. VUR usually is congenital and often familial

Vesicoureteric reflux is more common in females.

questions.text: A patient was admitted to ICU 48 hours after the fracture of the femur. The saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit was 100% but his Spo2 remained 60%. The patient is in a state of confusion. Chest radiograph showed lung fields to be clear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above clinical scenario is a fat embolism. Presence of respiratory insufficiency and altered mental status following a long bone fracture (fracture of the femur) favours the diagnosis.

Fat embolism syndrome results from the presence of numerous fat emboli within the microcirculation. It most commonly occurs after the fracture of the long bone or pelvis. They present with non-specific symptoms like tachypnea, tachycardia and fever that manifest within 24- 48 hours after the injury. Damage to the microvasculature of various organs leads to :

  • Mild hypoxia to rapidly progressing respiratory failure.
  • Depression of the central nervous system.
  • Petechial rashes
  • Hemorrhagic lesions of the retina.

questions.text: To diagnose post traumatic stress disorder, the symptoms should persist for more than ______.
questions.solution:
In post traumatic stress disorder, the symptoms persist for more than one month. 

Duration Condition
2 days to 1 month Acute stress reaction
More than 1 month Post-traumatic stress disorder
Symptoms occur after 6 months Delayed Post-traumatic stress disorder

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of Trauma and Stress related disorder

 
PTSD
Adjustment disorder
Bereavement
Stressor
Extreme traumatic events like rape or accident
Financial/ Illness/ Relationship issues
Death of a loved one
Time
Symptoms
develop within 6 months and persist more than 1 month
Symptoms
develop within 3 months and resolve in 6 months if stressor eliminated
Symptoms develop within 2 months and resolve within 2 months
Symptoms
Flashbacks and nightmares
Mostly depressive and anxiety
Mostly depressive

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding Allen's test?

choices.text: Used to confirm Ryle's tube position
Used to assess adequacy of collateral blood flow

questions.solution:
Allen's Test is used to test the adequacy of collateral blood flow to the hand. It mandatory before radial artery cannulation and sometimes, before drawing blood for arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis.

Method:

It is performed by occluding the radial and ulnar arteries and asking the patient to make a tight fist so as to exsanguinate the palm.

Then, the patient is asked to open the hand and the occlusion over the ulnar artery is released. If the palm remains pale for more than 6-10 seconds, it indicates reduced ulnar collateral flow.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with painful genital ulcers on vulva accompanied by bilateral lymphadenopathy. She has a history of multiple partners over the years. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple painful genital ulcers with bilateral lymphadenopathy are indicative of chancroid or soft chancre.

Chancroid is a type of sexually transmitted infection (STI) that is caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi, a gram-negative coccobacillus. It presents with painful genital ulceration along with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy that may develop into buboes. Auto-inoculation by the organism can result in new ulcers merging with the older ones. Hence, they are called "kissing ulcers".

The diagnosis is made clinically and can be supported by the gram stain findings, "school of fish"/"railroad track" appearance.

Treatment is recommended with a single dose of azithromycin (1g) or ceftriaxone (250mg).

Chancroid has gained clinical significance because it can increase the risk of HIV transmission. Hence, it is important to identify and treat these patients and to inform and treat their sexual partners from the last 3 months.

Image: Chancroidal penile ulceration

Other Options:

Option B: Granuloma inguinale (also known as donovanosis) is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with a painless papule or nodule that erodes into a beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges and often no lymphadenopathy.

Option C: In Lymphogranuloma venerum, a transient primary painless ulcer presents after 3–30 days of exposure and it usually presents on coronal sulcus in men and posterior vaginal wall in women.

Option D: Gonorrhoea is primarily a sexually transmitted bacterial infection caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae but vertical transmission during childbirth can occur. In men, it often presents as acute urethritis accompanied by a profuse urethral puru­lent discharge. Most women with early gonorrhea are asymptomatic. The primary site of infection in women is the cervix.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard) Donovanosis or granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

9-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 T.pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi Chlamydia trachomatis serovar L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base. Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy Single painless ulcer with clean base and raised, firm, border, painless lymphadenopathy Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges. No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry), painful inguinal lymphadenopathy Painless genital ulcer; painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/

Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline

questions.text: A child with features of bowing of legs and delayed walking presented to the OPD.  Radiograph of the hand was taken and given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
X-ray findings suggestive of active rickets are fraying, cupping of the metaphysis and widening of joint spaces.

Earliest radiological finding of rickets is loss of provisional zone of calcification

It is not surprising that these features are most prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: Rachitic rosary

questions.text: Radiotherapy is most useful in:
questions.solution: Seminoma is a highly radiosensitive tumor and hence radiotherapy is commonly used for treatment.
